.	O

areas	O
or	O

,	O

are	O

.	O

.	O
NETWORKS	O
AND	O
SYSTEMS	O
The	O
words	O
'	O
network	O
'	O
and	O
'	O
system	O
'	O
are	O
used	O
interchangeably	O
in	O
much	O
of	O
the	O
conservation	O
literature	O
to	O
describe	O
a	O
group	O
of	O
protected	O
areas	O
spread	O
across	O
a	O
country	O
or	O
region	O
.	O
The	O
use	O
of	O
the	O
two	O
words	O
can	O
be	O
confusing	O
as	O
neither	O
term	O
has	O
a	O
globally	O
accepted	O
definition	O
and	O
they	O
are	O
often	O
used	O
with	O
the	O
same	O
meaning	O
in	O
the	O
same	O
document	O
,	O
as	O
in	O
the	O
US	O
Federal	O
Register	O
(	O
US	O
Federal	O
Register	O
,	O
2000	O
)	O
.	O

there	O
are	O
exceptions	O
,	O
the	O
word	O
'	O
system	O
'	O
tends	O
to	O
be	O
used	O
most	O
frequently	O
for	O
protected	O
areas	O
in	O
general	O
,	O
and	O
also	O
for	O
terrestrial	O
protected	O
areas	O
.	O

LUCNWCPA	O

,	O
for	O

refer	O
to	O
national	O
protected	O
area	O
'	O
system	O
'	O
plans	O
(	O

,	O
1998	O
)	O
.	O

term	O
'	O
network	O
'	O

more	O
prevalent	O
among	O
MPA	O
practitioners	O
and	O
is	O
defined	O
by	O
WCPA	O
-	O
MARINE	O
as	O
follows	O
(	O
LUCNWCPA	O
,	O
2008a	O
)	O
:	O
A	O
collection	O
of	O
individual	O
MPAS	O
or	O
reserves	O
operating	O
co	O
-	O
operatively	O
and	O

at	O

a	O

.	O
Agardy	Person

(	O

'	O

are	O

.	O

.	O

PLATES	O
INTRODUCTION	O
Galls	O
are	O
abnormal	O
growths	O
on	O
the	O
stems	O
,	O
leaves	O
,	O
roots	O
,	O
or	O
other	O
parts	O
of	O
plants	O
,	O
caused	O
by	O
the	O
action	O
of	O
insects	Taxon
,	O
arachnids	Taxon
,	O
or	O
fungi	Taxon
,	O
or	O
by	O
unknown	O
agencies	O
.	O
Just	O
how	O
these	O
peculiar	O
structural	O
developments	O
are	O
brought	O
about	O
is	O
still	O
open	O
to	O
discussion	O
and	O
speculation	O
,	O
experimental	O
proofs	O
being	O
,	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
present	O
,	O
too	O
deficient	O
to	O
warrant	O
our	O
drawing	O
any	O
definite	O
conclusion	O
.	O
These	O
malformations	O
have	O
been	O
ascribed	O
to	O
various	O
causes	O
,	O
the	O
more	O
commonly	O
accepted	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
more	O
reasonable	O
,	O
explanations	O
being	O
the	O
following	O
:	O
2	O
1	O
,	O
a	O
severe	O
mechanical	O
injury	O
to	O
certain	O
parts	O
of	O
the	O
plant	O
;	O
2	O
,	O
a	O
continuous	O
mechanical	O
irritation	O
;	O
3	O
,	O
secretion	O
of	O
chemical	O
stimulus	O
by	O
the	O
causal	O
animal	O
or	O
fungus	O
.	O
One	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
combination	O
of	O
two	O
or	O
all	O
,	O
of	O
these	O
causes	O
may	O
give	O
rise	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
galls	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
formation	O
of	O
zobcecidia	O
,	O
the	O
third	O
factor	O
—	O
that	O
is	O
,	O
the	O
action	O
of	O
the	O
virus	Taxon
secreted	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
oviposition	O
or	O
during	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
parasite	O
—	O
is	O
probably	O
the	O
most	O
important	O
,	O
the	O
first	O
two	O
being	O
of	O
minor	O
or	O
absolutely	O
no	O
use	O
whatever	O
.	O
This	O
fact	O
was	O
shown	O
by	O
Molliard	O
in	O
connection	O
with	O
his	O
experiments	O
on	O
Aulax	Taxon
papaveris	Taxon
Perris	Taxon
,	O
a	O
cynipid	O
gall	O
maker	O
on	O
the	O
pistil	O
of	O
Papaver	Taxon
rhoeas	Taxon
Pall	Taxon
.	O
3	O

time	O
to	O
time	O
he	O
removed	O
a	O

of	O

of	O
Papaver	Taxon
.	O

treatment	O
resulted	O
in	O
the	O
formation	O
of	O
galls	O
which	O
resembled	O
in	O
all	O
respects	O
those	O
formed	O

the	O

of	O
the	O

the	O
animal	O

.	O

.	O

are	O

and	O

.	O

to	O
bird	O
collecting	O

CLASSIFICATION	O
OF	O
ILANG	Taxon
-	O
ILANG	Taxon
OIL	O

that	O
ilang	Taxon
-	O
ilang	Taxon
oil	O

.	O

basis	O

MAMMALS	O
OF	O
THE	O
PHILIPPINE	GeographicalLocation
ISLANDS	GeographicalLocation
.	O
41	O
Many	O
of	O
these	O
names	O
are	O
surely	O
synonyms	O
,	O
while	O
a	O
few	O
are	O
probably	O
valid	O
for	O
species	O
or	O
subspecies	O
of	O
Philippine	Taxon
deer	Taxon
.	O
Until	O
series	O
of	O
deer	O
skulls	O
from	O
all	O
parts	O
of	O
the	O
Philippine	GeographicalLocation
Islands	GeographicalLocation
,	O
and	O
especially	O
from	O
the	O
type	O
localities	O
of	O
all	O
described	O
forms	O
,	O
are	O
assembled	O
for	O
study	O
,	O
it	O
will	O
be	O
impossible	O
satisfactorily	O
to	O
deal	O
with	O
these	O
names	O
.	O
I	O
have	O
arranged	O
them	O
alphabetically	O
by	O
species	O
,	O
regardless	O
of	O
the	O

Habits	Taxon

Throughout	O
the	O
ages	O
sharks	O
have	O
been	O
of	O
well	O
-	O
nigh	O
universal	O
interest	O
.	O
Without	O
the	O

colors	O
or	O

of	O
some	O

and	O
grace	O

others	O

they	O

attention	O
.	O

as	O
a	O
rule	O
of	O
a	O

uniform	O
gray	O
or	O

without	O

form	O

.	O

of	O

their	O
more	O
degenerate	O
and	O

active	O

the	O
skates	O
and	O

.	O

a	O

only	O

.	O

MAMMALS	O

in	O

of	O

the	O
average	O
sportsman	O

they	O
are	O
received	O
and	O
what	O

is	O

to	O
material	O

to	O

.	O

skins	O

small	O

really	O

Museum	O

of	O
mammals	O
in	O

most	O

styles	O

.	O

in	O
the	O
medium	O

prepared	O
.	O

to	O

tail	O

up	O

DISEASES	O
OF	O
THE	O

.	O

of	O
the	O
kidneys	O
occurred	O
more	O
frequently	O

III	O

INTRODUCTION	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
received	O
numerous	O
requests	O
for	O
information	O
regarding	O
the	O
commercial	O
fisheries	O
of	O
the	O
Philippine	GeographicalLocation
Islands	GeographicalLocation
,	O
especially	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
different	O
kinds	O
of	O
edible	O
fish	O
and	O
their	O
abundance	O
;	O
the	O
location	O
of	O
fishing	O
-	O
banks	O
and	O
the	O
methods	O
of	O
capture	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
also	O
been	O
asked	O
if	O
fishing	O
,	O
entered	O
into	O
as	O
a	O
commercial	O
venture	O
,	O
would	O
be	O
profitable	O
.	O

is	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
answering	O
some	O
of	O
these	O
questions	O
that	O
Part	O
I	O
of	O
this	O
series	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
my	O
personal	O
observation	O
in	O
the	O
various	O
islands	O
of	O
the	O
group	O
during	O
the	O
past	O
year	O
and	O
a	O
half	O
,	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
.	O

is	O
hoped	O
that	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
together	O
with	O
others	O
to	O
follow	O
—	O
namely	O
,	O
Part	O
II	O
,	O
Sponge	O
Fisheries	O
;	O
Part	O
III	O
,	O
Pearl	O

;	O

THE	O
ANCHOVIES	Taxon
.	O
Family	O

.	O
(	O

.	O

,	O

,	O

Anchovia	Taxon
commersoniana	Taxon
(	Taxon

)	O
,	Taxon

in	O

in	O

,	O

anahhat	Taxon
in	O

.	O

and	O

than	O
the	O
hills	O
.	O

common	Taxon
anchovy	Taxon
(	O
dilis	Taxon
)	O
is	O
found	O
in	O
great	O

of	O

SCIENTIFIC	O

VALUE	O
Land	O

have	O
been	O
used	O
extensively	O
for	O
research	O

the	O
basis	O
of	O
natural	O
selection	O

of	O
the	O
high	O

genetically	O

(	O

.	O

INTRODUCTION	O
.	O
The	O
Steere	O
Expedition	O
to	O
the	O
Philippines	GeographicalLocation
went	O
out	O
from	O
the	O
University	O
of	O
Michigan	O
in	O
the	O
year	O
1887	TemporalExpression
,	O
and	O
spent	O
about	O
twelve	TemporalExpression
months	TemporalExpression
in	O
the	O
Islands	O
.	O
The	O
object	O
of	O
the	O
expedition	O
was	O
to	O
make	O
general	O
zoological	O
collections	O
,	O
at	O
the	O
same	O
time	O
visiting	O
as	O
many	O
distinct	O
localities	O
as	O
possible	O
,	O
so	O
that	O
the	O
distribution	O
of	O
species	O
in	O
the	O
islands	O
themselves	O
could	O
be	O
studied	O
.	O
Fifteen	O
of	O
the	O
larger	O
islands	O
,	O
situated	O
in	O
all	O
parts	O
of	O
the	O
group	O
,	O
were	O
visited	O
,	O
and	O
from	O
two	TemporalExpression
to	TemporalExpression
six	TemporalExpression
weeks	TemporalExpression
spent	O
upon	O
each	O
.	O
This	O
amount	O
of	O
time	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
party	O
of	O
five	O
collectors	O
from	O
the	O
United	GeographicalLocation
States	GeographicalLocation
,	O
and	O
such	O
native	O
help	O
as	O
could	O
be	O
obtained	O
,	O
sufficed	O
to	O
make	O
very	O
large	O
,	O
though	O
by	O
no	O
means	O
exhaustive	O
collections	O
of	O
vertebrates	O
,	O
and	O
important	O
collections	O
in	O
several	O
groups	O
of	O
invertebrates	O
.	O
As	O
island	O
after	O
island	O
was	O
reached	O
and	O
collected	O
upon	O
by	O
the	O
party	O
,	O
the	O
discovery	O
was	O
made	O
that	O
the	O
group	O
is	O
divided	O
into	O
several	O
quite	O
distinct	O
zoological	O

,	O
which	O
I	O
have	O

to	O
be	O
sub	O
-	O
provinces	O

and	O
have	O

Philippines	GeographicalLocation

Papayotin	O
(	O

1059	O

matter	O
5303	O

acid	O
0443	O
Peptic	O
material	O
and	O
salts	O
7100	O
Water	O
74971	O
The	O
milky	O
juice	O
is	O
neutral	O
and	O
coagulates	O
rapidly	O
,	O
separating	O
in	O
two	O
parts	O
a	O
kind	O
of	O
insoluble	O
pulp	O
and	O
a	O
limpid	O
colorless	O
serum	O
.	O
If	O

with	O
fibrin	O
,	O
raw	O
meat	O
,	O
white	O
of	O
egg	O
or	O
gluten	O
it	O
gradually	O
softens	O
them	O
and	O
completely	O
dissolves	O
them	O
in	O
3	O
or	O
4	O
hours	O
in	O
vitro	O
at	O
40	O
°	O
C	O
.	O

with	O
milk	O
it	O

and	O
soon	O
precipitates	O
the	O
casein	O
which	O
is	O

dissolved	O
a	O
little	O
later	O
.	O

digests	O

and	O
tape	Taxon
-	O
worms	Taxon
and	O
the	O
false	O
membrane	O
of	O
croup	O
,	O
in	O
a	O
few	O
hours	O
.	O

to	O

and	O
Bouchut	O
papain	O
is	O
prepared	O
as	O
follows	O
The	O
fluid	O

or	O
the	O

of	O
the	O

is	O
precipitated	O
by	O
the	O
addition	O
of	O
ten	O
times	O
the	O
volume	O
of	O
alcohol	O
.	O
The	O
precipitate	O
,	O
after	O
treating	O
again	O
with	O
concentrated	O
alcohol	O
,	O
is	O
dissolved	O
in	O
water	O
and	O
the	O
addition	O
of	O
sub	O
-	O
acetate	O
of	O
lead	O

the	O
albuminoids	O
and	O
peptones	O
but	O
does	O
not	O
precipitate	O
the	O
japan	GeographicalLocation
.	O
The	O
liquid	O
is	O
filtered	O
and	O
the	O
lead	O
salts	O
separated	O
by	O
means	O
of	O
a	O
current	O
of	O
hydrogen	O
sulphide	O
.	O

is	O
filtered	O
again	O
and	O
alcohol	O
added	O
gradually	O
,	O
which	O
process	O
first	O
precipitates	O

of	O

may	O

passed	O
through	O
the	O
filter	O
,	O
and	O
then	O
the	O
papain	O
.	O
Papain	O
is	O
an	O
amorphous	O
substance	O
,	O
perfectly	O
white	O
,	O
soluble	O
in	O
water	O
,	O
insipid	O
,	O
odorless	O
.	O
An	O
aqueous	O
solution	O
,	O

CONCLUSIONS	O
This	O
chapter	O
summarizes	O
the	O
ley	O
findings	O
of	O
the	O
report	O
and	O

some	O

challenges	O
that	O
are	O
being	O
encountered	O
in	O
establishing	O
MPA	O
networks	O
.	O
91	O
.	O
PROGRESS	O
IN	O
ESTABLISHING	O
MPA	O
NETWORKS	O
The	O
report	O
does	O
not	O
provide	O
a	O
globally	O
comprehensive	O
review	O
but	O
general	O
conclusions	O
can	O
be	O
drawn	O
,	O
as	O
the	O
many	O
initiatives	O
underway	O
are	O
providing	O
a	O
solid	O
body	O
of	O
experience	O
on	O
how	O
MPA	O
networks	O
can	O
be	O
established	O
in	O
practice	O
,	O
and	O
how	O
the	O
process	O
may	O
need	O
to	O
respond	O
to	O
different	O
needs	O
and	O
priorities	O
.	O
The	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
approaches	O
and	O
different	O
spatial	O
or	O
geographical	O
scales	O
being	O
used	O
makes	O
comparison	O
difficult	O
but	O
there	O
is	O
much	O
value	O
in	O
the	O
experimentation	O
underway	O
.	O
A	O
key	O
finding	O
is	O
the	O
length	O
of	O
time	O
needed	O
to	O
develop	O
MPA	O
networks	O
,	O
if	O
stakeholders	O
are	O
to	O
be	O
fully	O
involved	O
and	O
if	O
scientific	O
design	O
principles	O
are	O
to	O
be	O
applied	O
.	O
The	O
principle	O
of	O
representation	O
is	O
relatively	O
easy	O
to	O
address	O
,	O
provided	O
adequate	O
classifications	O
and	O
biodiversity	O
distribution	O
(	O
or	O
suitable	O
proxies	O
)	O
are	O
available	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
principles	O
of	O
adequacy	O
,	O
resilience	O
and	O
connectivity	O
are	O
proving	O
more	O
difficult	O
to	O
incorporate	O
,	O
since	O
specific	O
guidelines	O
on	O
applying	O
them	O
are	O
still	O
lacking	O
due	O
to	O
dearth	O
of	O
clear	O
scientific	O
understanding	O
.	O
'	O
Rules	O
of	O
thumb	O
'	O
are	O
being	O
used	O
where	O
possible	O
(	O
see	O
LUCNWCPA	O
,	O
2008a	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
rapid	O
growth	O
of	O
research	O
in	O
this	O
field	O
means	O
that	O
new	O
information	O
is	O
constantly	O
becoming	O
available	O
.	O

.	O

28	O
THE	O
FOREST	O
DISTRICT	O
OF	O
SOUTH	GeographicalLocation
TAYABAS	GeographicalLocation
.	O
I	O
.	O
GENERAL	O
DESCRIPTION	O
OF	O
THE	O
DISTRICT	O
.	O
The	O
forest	O
district	O
of	O
south	GeographicalLocation
Tayabas	GeographicalLocation
extends	O
from	O
the	O
south	O
boundary	O
of	O
the	O
Province	GeographicalLocation
of	GeographicalLocation
Batangas	GeographicalLocation
to	O
the	O
southern	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
Tayabas	GeographicalLocation
Peninsula	GeographicalLocation
,	O
with	O
a	O
total	O
coast	Habitat
line	O
of	O
about	O
90	O
miles	O
,	O
and	O
an	O
average	O
width	O
of	O
7	O
miles	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
north	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
district	O
Mount	GeographicalLocation
Banahao	GeographicalLocation
,	O
an	O
extinct	O
volcano	O
,	O
rises	O
to	O
a	O
height	O
of	O
about	O
5	O
,	O
000	O
feet	O
,	O
and	O
from	O
it	O
extends	O
a	O
central	Habitat
ridge	Habitat
running	O
through	O
the	O
whole	O
province	O
,	O
with	O
an	O
average	O
height	O
of	O
about	O
500	O
feet	O
.	O
Beginning	O
at	O
Laguimanoc	GeographicalLocation
,	O
the	O
ridge	O
extends	O
farther	O
back	O
into	O
the	O
interior	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
row	O
of	O
low	Habitat
hills	Habitat
runs	O
along	O
the	O
coast	Habitat
.	O
Many	O
rivers	Habitat
,	O
some	O
of	O
them	O
of	O
considerable	O
size	O
,	O
come	O
down	O
from	O
the	O
central	Habitat
sierra	Habitat
and	O
break	O
through	O
the	O
low	Habitat
hills	Habitat
along	O
the	O
coast	Habitat
.	O
In	O
some	O
of	O
the	O
rivers	O
the	O
tide	O
water	O
runs	O
back	O
a	O
distance	O
of	O
8	O
miles	O
,	O
such	O
rivers	O
being	O
available	O
for	O
floating	O
timber	O
to	O
the	O
coast	O
.	O
Beginning	O
at	O
Catanauan	GeographicalLocation
,	O
grass	Habitat
lands	Habitat
extend	O
between	O
the	O
mountains	Habitat
and	O
the	O
coast	Habitat
.	O
All	O
the	O
rivers	O
have	O
more	O
or	O
less	O
a	O
swamp	Habitat
forest	Habitat
on	O
the	O
lower	O
part	O
of	O
their	O
course	O
;	O
back	O
of	O
these	O
are	O
clearings	O
and	O
cocoanut	Habitat
plantations	Habitat
,	O
and	O
finally	O
the	O
forest	Habitat
,	O
which	O
to	O
a	O
large	O
extent	O
is	O
already	O
deprived	O
of	O
its	O
valuable	O
species	O
.	O
Nowhere	O
in	O
this	O
district	O
is	O
lumbering	O
being	O
done	O
on	O
a	O
large	O
scale	O
,	O
30	O
,	O
000	O
cubic	O
feet	O
being	O
the	O
greatest	O
amount	O
of	O
timber	O
cut	O
by	O
any	O
one	O
licensee	O
during	O
the	O
previous	O
year	O
.	O
In	O
Unisan	GeographicalLocation
,	O
Pitogo	GeographicalLocation
,	O
and	O
Laguimanoc	GeographicalLocation
there	O
are	O
shipyards	O
where	O
sailboats	O
and	O
small	O
steamers	O
are	O
being	O
built	O
;	O
five	O
licensees	O
are	O
engaged	O
in	O
this	O
business	O
,	O
each	O
one	O
finishing	O
about	O
one	O
boat	O
in	O
two	O
years	O
.	O
There	O
is	O
a	O
small	O
sawmill	O
with	O
one	O
circular	O
saw	O
in	O
Lucena	GeographicalLocation
,	O
but	O
it	O
does	O
little	O
business	O
.	O
The	O
owners	O
buy	O
the	O
greater	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
timber	O
and	O
only	O
run	O
the	O
mill	O
when	O
they	O
have	O
orders	O
for	O
a	O
certain	O
amount	O
of	O
sawn	O
material	O
,	O
all	O
of	O
which	O
is	O
used	O
locally	O
.	O
Considerable	O
firewood	O
and	O
some	O
resin	O
are	O

in	O
this	O
district	O
and	O
shipped	O
to	O
Manila	GeographicalLocation
.	O
The	O
most	O
important	O
industry	O
in	O
this	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
Province	GeographicalLocation
of	GeographicalLocation
Tayabas	GeographicalLocation
is	O
the	O
trade	O
of	O
copra	O
,	O
and	O
many	O

palms	Taxon
,	O
about	O

-	O

are	O

fruit	O
at	O
the	O
present	O

.	O
II	O
.	O
FOREST	O
AREA	O
.	O
Description	O
of	O
stand	O
,	O
silvicultural	O
features	O
,	O
reproduction	O
,	O
etc	O
.	O
—	O
The	O
total	O
forest	Habitat
area	O
comprises	O
about	O
300	O
square	O
miles	O
,	O
one	O
-	O
half	O
of	O
which	O
,	O
due	O
mainly	O
to	O
the	O
great	O
distance	O
from	O
the	O
shore	O
of	O
some	O
of	O
the	O
timber	O
,	O
and	O
also	O
the	O
lack	O
of	O
suitable	O
transportation	O
,	O
is	O
virgin	Habitat
forest	Habitat
.	O
In	O
that	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
forest	O
where	O
lumbering	O
is	O
carried	O
on	O
at	O
present	O
,	O
and	O
which	O
has	O
been	O
lumbered	O
for	O
almost	O
one	O
hundred	O
years	O
,	O
very	O
few	O
of	O
the	O
valuable	O
species	O
are	O
left	O
,	O
and	O
those	O
remaining	O
are	O
mostly	O
rotten	O
or	O
of	O
such	O
large	O
size	O
that	O
they	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
taken	O
out	O
.	O
The	O
greater	O
number	O
of	O
trees	O
in	O
the	O
stand	O
belong	O
to	O
the	O
second	O
and	O
third	O
groups	O
.	O
The	O
family	O
Dipterocarpacese	Taxon
is	O
largely	O
represented	O
by	O
the	O
following	O
species	O
:	O
Yacal	Taxon
,	O
apitong	Taxon
,	O
lauan	Taxon
,	O
and	O
hagachac	Taxon
.	O
The	O
most	O
important	O
of	O
the	O
other	O
species	O
found	O
are	O
narra	Taxon
,	O
dungon	Taxon
,	O
supa	Taxon
,	O
banaba	Taxon
,	O
guijo	Taxon
,	O
and	O
macaasin	Taxon
.	O
The	O
reproduction	O
in	O
general	O
is	O
fair	O
and	O
that	O
of	O
the	O
family	O
Dipterocarpaceae	Taxon
good	O
.	O
The	O
underbrush	O
,	O
with	O
few	O
exceptions	O
,	O
is	O
very	O
dense	O
,	O
consisting	O
mostly	O
of	O
bejuco	Taxon
(	O
at	O
least	O
three	O
different	O
kinds	O
)	O
,	O
palma	Taxon
brava	Taxon
,	O
timac	Taxon
,	O
and	O
saplings	O
.	O
In	O
most	O
instances	O
the	O
underlying	O
rock	O
is	O
limestone	Habitat
,	O
sometimes	O
soft	O
,	O
sometimes	O
very	O
hard	Habitat
tufa	Habitat
.	O
Sandstone	Habitat
and	O
quartzites	Habitat
are	O
also	O
found	O
in	O
a	O
few	O
places	O
.	O

varies	O
from	O
an	O
almost	O
pure	Habitat
sand	Habitat
to	O
heavy	Habitat
clay	Habitat

.	O

during	O

rainy	O
season	O
and	O
cracks	O
when	O

to	O
the	O
sun	O

62	O
THE	O
MEDICINAL	O
PLANTS	O
OF	O
THE	O
PHILIPPINES	GeographicalLocation
bitter	O
;	O
specific	O
gravity	O
0911	O
.	O
It	O
boils	O
at	O
228	O
,	O
is	O
slightly	O
soluble	O
in	O
water	O
,	O
and	O
soluble	O
in	O
absolute	O
alcohol	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
promptly	O
oxidized	O
by	O
nitric	O
acid	O
,	O
and	O
is	O
converted	O
into	O
pelargonic	O
acid	O
and	O
other	O
fatty	O
acids	O
.	O
Rutin	O
(	O
or	O
rutinic	O
acid	O
)	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
Weiss	Person
,	O
is	O
a	O
glucoside	O
which	O
exists	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
fine	O
needles	O
,	O
bright	O
yellow	O
T	O
in	O
color	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
slightly	O
soluble	O
in	O
cold	O
water	O
and	O
more	O
so	O
in	O
boiling	O
water	O
.	O
It	O
melts	O
at	O
190	O
,	O
and	O
solidifies	O
at	O
freezing	O
point	O
,	O
forming	O
a	O
resinous	O
mass	O
.	O
Its	O
physiological	O
properties	O
are	O
as	O
yet	O
unknown	O
.	O
The	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
plant	O
employed	O
is	O
the	O
leaves	O
,	O
which	O
owe	O
their	O
property	O
,	O
apparently	O
,	O
to	O
the	O
essential	O
oil	O
they	O
contain	O
,	O
from	O
which	O
they	O
also	O
derive	O
their	O
strong	O
and	O
disagreeable	O
odor	O
and	O
their	O
bitter	O
,	O
acrid	O
and	O
nauseous	O
taste	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
used	O
principally	O
as	O
a	O
uterine	O
stimulant	O
or	O
emmenagogue	O
,	O
for	O
which	O
purpose	O
it	O
is	O
given	O
in	O
doses	O
of	O
010	O
-	O
015	O
centigrams	O
of	O
the	O
freshly	O
powdered	O
leaf	O
and	O
005	O
-	O
010	O
centigrams	O
of	O
the	O
fresh	O
leaves	O
infused	O
in	O
a	O
liter	O
of	O
water	O
.	O
The	O
dry	O
powder	O
of	O
the	O
leaf	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
used	O
because	O
the	O
essential	O
oil	O
volatilizes	O
and	O
a	O
large	O
proportion	O
of	O
it	O
is	O
lost	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
active	O
principle	O
of	O
the	O
drug	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
an	O
agent	O
which	O
should	O
be	O
prescribed	O
with	O
the	O
greatest	O
prudence	O
for	O
large	O
doses	O
are	O
poisonous	O
even	O
to	O
the	O
point	O
of	O
causing	O
death	O
.	O
The	O
symptoms	O
following	O
such	O
doses	O
are	O
colic	O
,	O
vomiting	O
,	O
bloody	O
diarrhoea	O
and	O
tenesmus	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
also	O
used	O
as	O
an	O
antihemorrhagic	O
after	O
childbirth	O
,	O
but	O
its	O
action	O
is	O
slow	O
,	O
not	O
being	O
felt	O
for	O
several	O
hours	O
after	O
the	O
administration	O
of	O
the	O
drug	O
;	O
for	O
this	O
reason	O
it	O
cannot	O
take	O
the	O
place	O
of	O
ergot	O
,	O
though	O
it	O
seems	O
to	O
be	O
superior	O
to	O
the	O
latter	O
in	O
passive	O
hemorrhages	O
.	O

essential	O
oil	O
is	O
given	O
internally	O
in	O
doses	O
of	O
2	O
-	O
6	O
drops	O
on	O
a	O
piece	O
of	O
sugar	O
.	O

is	O
sometimes	O

DANGEROUS	O
SEA	O
LIFE	O
(	O
3	O
)	O
Stonefish	Taxon
,	O
Synanceja	Taxon
Zebrafish	Taxon
are	O
a	O
beautiful	O
and	O
ornate	O
shallow	O
water	O
fish	O
of	O
tropical	Habitat
and	Habitat
temperate	Habitat
seas	Habitat
.	O
They	O
parade	O
about	O
coral	Habitat
reefs	Habitat
,	O
spreading	O
their	O
fan	O
-	O
like	O
and	O
lacy	O
fins	O
in	O
much	O
the	O
same	O
manner	O
as	O
peacocks	Taxon
.	O
They	O
are	O
found	O
in	O
pairs	O
and	O
present	O
an	O
invitation	O
to	O
disaster	O
if	O
touched	O
.	O
Beneath	O
the	O
finery	O
are	O
hidden	O
long	O
,	O
straight	O
needle	O
-	O
sharp	O
fin	O
spines	O
which	O
are	O
a	O
spectacular	O
menace	O
to	O
anyone	O
exploring	O
tropical	O
coral	Habitat
areas	Habitat
.	O
These	O
fish	O
are	O
armed	O
with	O
as	O
many	O
as	O
18	O
potentially	O
lethal	O
spines	O
,	O
each	O
equipped	O
with	O
venom	O
.	O
The	O
scorpionfish	Taxon
are	O
inhabitants	O
of	O
shallow	O
water	O
bays	O
and	O
reefs	O
.	O
A	O
habit	O
of	O
concealing	O
themselves	O
in	O
crevices	Habitat
among	Habitat
debris	Habitat
,	O
under	Habitat
rocks	Habitat
,	O
or	O
in	Habitat
seaweed	Habitat
along	O
with	O
a	O
nearly	O
perfect	O
protective	O
coloration	O
makes	O
this	O
fish	O
almost	O
invisible	O
.	O
Upon	O
discovery	O
and	O
removal	O
from	O
the	O
water	O
these	O
fish	O
erect	O
spiny	O
fins	O
and	O
spread	O
out	O
gill	O
covers	O
in	O
an	O
aggressive	O
display	O
.	O
Stonefish	Taxon
are	O
encountered	O
in	O
tidepools	Habitat
and	O
shoal	Habitat
areas	Habitat
.	O
They	O
lie	O
motionless	O
while	O
concealed	O
or	O
even	O
partly	O
buried	O
and	O
are	O
fearless	O
or	O
even	O
disinterested	O
in	O
any	O
careless	O
intrusion	O
.	O
This	O
presents	O
a	O
dangerous	O
situation	O
to	O
anyone	O
with	O
bare	O
feet	O
.	O
The	O
fish	O
is	O
equipped	O
with	O
as	O
many	O
as	O
13	O
dorsal	O
spines	O
,	O
3	O
anal	O
spines	O
,	O
and	O
2	O
pelvic	O
spines	O
;	O
all	O
are	O
short	O
and	O
heavy	O
with	O
enlarged	O
venom	O
glands	O
.	O
In	O
natural	O
concealment	O
,	O
the	O
fish	O
looks	O
like	O
a	O
piece	O
of	O
mud	O
or	O
debris	O
.	O
Symptoms	O
produced	O
by	O
all	O
3	O
types	O
of	O
scorpionfish	Taxon
vary	O
in	O
degree	O
,	O
but	O
the	O
pain	O
is	O
immediate	O
,	O
sharp	O
,	O
and	O
radiates	O
.	O
Pain	O
may	O
cause	O
a	O
victim	O
to	O
thrash	O
in	O
a	O
wild	O
manner	O
,	O
scream	O
,	O
or	O
lose	O
consciousness	O
.	O
The	O
immediate	O
wound	O
area	O
may	O
be	O
pale	O
,	O
surrounded	O
by	O
a	O
zone	O
or	O
redness	O
,	O
swelling	O
,	O
and	O
heat	O
.	O
Paralysis	O
of	O
an	O
entire	O
arm	O
or	O
leg	O
may	O
result	O
,	O
and	O
intense	O
swelling	O
of	O
a	O
member	O
may	O
impair	O
movements	O
.	O
Many	O
other	O
symptoms	O
may	O
also	O
be	O
present	O
.	O
Death	O
may	O
be	O
the	O
result	O
of	O
an	O
encounter	O
,	O
or	O
the	O
victim	O
may	O
recover	O
after	O
months	O
of	O
treatment	O
but	O
with	O
general	O
health	O
impaired	O
.	O
Treatment	O
,	O
as	O
for	O
other	O
venomous	O
fish	O
stings	O
,	O
must	O
be	O
administered	O
promptly	O
.	O
Prevention	O
of	O
the	O
sting	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
previous	O
experiences	O
,	O
depends	O
udon	O
the	O
warning	O
of	O
individuals	O
not	O
to	O
handle	O
scorpionfish	O
with	O
unprotected	O
hands	O
.	O
Attraction	O
of	O
the	O
uninitiated	O
to	O
touch	O
the	O
lacy	O
fins	O
or	O
the	O
placing	O
of	O
hands	O
or	O
feet	O
in	O
crevices	Habitat
inhabited	O
by	O
the	O
fish	O
must	O
be	O
prevented	O
to	O
avoid	O
the	O
danger	O
.	O
Recommended	O
treatment	O
of	O
Venomous	O
Fish	O
Stings	O
Treatment	O
of	O
venomous	O
fish	O
stings	O
should	O
be	O
directed	O
to	O
the	O
achievement	O
of	O
3	O
objectives	O
:	O
1	O
.	O
Alleviate	O
pain	O
.	O
2	O
.	O
Combat	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
the	O
venom	O
.	O
3	O
.	O
Prevent	O
follow	O
-	O
up	O
infections	O
.	O
The	O
pain	O
is	O
generally	O
a	O
direct	O
result	O
of	O
the	O
damage	O
caused	O
by	O
the	O
spine	O
.	O
Additional	O
effects	O
are	O
produced	O
by	O
the	O
venom	O
and	O
the	O
introduction	O
of	O
slime	O
and	O
foreign	O
material	O
.	O
Certain	O
stings	O
,	O
as	O
in	O
the	O
case	O
of	O
rays	O
and	O
catfish	O
,	O
may	O
produce	O
greater	O
damage	O
if	O
spines	O
are	O
recurved	O
or	O
barbed	O
edges	O
are	O
present	O
.	O
Such	O
wounds	O
should	O
be	O
carefully	O
washed	O
out	O
or	O
irrigated	O
with	O
cold	O
salt	O
water	O
or	O
with	O
sterile	O
saline	O
,	O
if	O
available	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
advisable	O
in	O
most	O
cases	O
to	O
make	O
a	O
small	O
incision	O
across	O
the	O
sting	O
wound	O
.	O

.	O
